As I reflected on these patterns, I realized that my tendency to label others was deeply ingrained. But what struck me most was how these labels influenced my own behavior. Conversely, when I met someone deemed "exceptionally talented," I'd often find myself trying to learn from them, seeking their advice and input.

It wasn't until I had a particularly heated argument with a coworker that I began to see the impact of my labeling more clearly. We were discussing a project, and I'd made a comment about his lack of experience leading to a flawed approach. In that moment, I realized that my labeling had created a power imbalance, making him feel belittled and defensive.

Since then, I've made a conscious effort to avoid these labels, recognizing that they're not only subjective but also potentially damaging. It's not always easy, though - old habits die hard, after all. Still, I'm working on cultivating a more nuanced understanding of those around me, one that acknowledges the complexity and diversity of human experience.
